facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 54 of 1956. Appeals by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated May 31, 1955 in Criminal Revision No. 102 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1955, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No. 102 of 1955,

facts.text: Patna High Court revision arose from Sessions Judge judgment dated January 10, 1955 in Criminal Revision No. 43 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated January 10, 1955, of the Court of the Sessions Judge of Manbhum-Singhbhum of Purulia in Criminal Re-vision No. 43 of 1954.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad passed order of discharge under s.494 CrPC consenting to withdrawal against Mahesh Desai.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals arise out of an order of discharge passed by the Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure on his companysenting to the withdrawal

facts.text: Prosecution launched on first information of Ram Naresh Pandey against 28 persons for murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey.

anchor.surface_text: of the Public Prosecutor from a prosecution pending before him in so far as it was against the appellant. Mahesh Desai, one of the accused therein. The prosecution was launched on the first information of one Ram Naresh Pandey as against 28 persons

facts.text: Murder of Nand Kumar Chaubey, peon of colliery in Bagdigi, committed in course of riot on February 20, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: about the companymission of the murder of one Nand Kumar Chaubey, a peon of a companyliery in Bagdigi, companymitted in the companyrse of a serious riot on February 20, 1954.

facts.text: Riot resulted from differences between two rival labour-unions in connection with a strike.

anchor.surface_text: This was said to have resulted from differences between two rival labour-unions in companynection with a strike.

facts.text: Prosecution against most accused under sections including s.302 IPC for actual participation in murder.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution as against most of the other persons is under various sections of the Indian Penal Code including s. 302, on the ground of their actual participation in the companymission of the murder.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai accused under s.302/109 IPC for abetting murder by speeches and exhortations day previous to murder.

anchor.surface_text: But as against the appellant, Mahesh Desai, it is only under s. 302 /109 of the Indian Penal Code, the part ascribed to him in the first information report being that he abetted the murder by reason of certain speeches and exhortations at meetings or group-talks the day previous to the murder.

facts.text: Withdrawal application made by Public Prosecutor on December 6, 1954, during committal stage before any evidence taken.

anchor.surface_text: The application for withdrawal as against the appellant was made on December 6, 1954, when the matter was pending before the Magistrate in the companymittal stage and before any evidence was actually taken.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor applied for withdrawal on ground that evidence available would not be just and expedient to proceed, evidence meagre and dubious.

anchor.surface_text: It was made by the Public Prosecutor on the ground that on the evidence available it would number be just and expedient to proceed with the prosecution of Sri Mahesh Desai and that therefore it was necessary to withdraw the case against Sri Mahesh Desai only .

facts.text: Magistrate granted consent and discharged Mahesh Desai.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate dealt with the ,matter in a fairly reasoned order and was of the opinion that there was numberreason to withhold the companysent that was applied for. He accordingly discharged the accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge upheld discharge order on revision by first informant and widow.

anchor.surface_text: That-order was upheld by the learned Sessions Judge on, revision petition against it filed jointly by the first informant in the case and by the, widow of the murdered person.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside discharge, directed Magistrate to record evidence and consider prima facie case.

anchor.surface_text: These private parties pursued the matter further and applied to the High Court in revision. The learned Chief Justice who dealt with it was of the opinion that the companysent should number have been granted.

facts.text: State appealed to Supreme Court against High Court order, leave granted.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate General of the State has companye up before this Court against the order of the learned Chief Justice. Leave was granted because it was urged that the view taken by the learned Chief Justice

facts.text: Mahesh Desai appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The aggrieved party, Mahesh Desai, also has companye up by special leave and both these appeals are disposed of by this judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on January 31, 1957 by JAGANNADHADAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. January 31. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-These appeals arise out of an order of discharge passed by the Subordinate Judge-Magistrate of Dhanbad

facts.text: Mahesh Desai held meetings and advocated closing Bagdigi cable plant and assaulting dalals.

anchor.surface_text: These persons, viz., Mahesh Desai and others,regularly held meetings and advocated for closing Bagdigi cable plant and companye plant and assaulting the dalals.

facts.text: On Friday morning, Mahesh Desai told labourers at Bagdigi to stop work.

anchor.surface_text: Yesterday, Friday morning when some labourers were going to resume their work in 8 No. pit, at Lodna the striking labourers created disturbance there and the labourers of that place who were going to resume work companyld number do so.

facts.text: Mahesh Desai addressed meeting at 6:30 p.m., exhorted labourers to prevent work resumption.

anchor.surface_text: Jadubans Tiwary, the overman of Bagdigi Colliery, said that Sheoji Singh and Ramdhar Singh had told him that in the evening at about 6-30 p.m. Mahesh Desai came to Bagdigi Mahabir Asthan Chala, companylected 120 to 125 labourers and held a meeting

facts.text: Evidence against Mahesh Desai meagre, single item of dubious nature, unlikely to establish prima facie case.

anchor.surface_text: It was elicited in the companyrse of the arguments before the learned Magistrate. that the position of the Public Prosecutor was, that the evidence regarding the companyplicity of this accused was meagre and that there WAS only, a single item of evidence of a dubious nature against him.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order, restored Magistrate's discharge order.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial companyrt is hereby restored.

issues.text: whether where an application for withdrawal under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is made on the ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence that is available, it is an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent before evidence is taken, if it was reasonably satisfied, otherwise, that the evidence, if actually taken, is not likely to result in conviction.

holdings.text: Where an application for withdrawal under s.494 CrPC is made on ground of insufficiency of evidence, it is not improper for Court to grant consent before evidence taken if reasonably satisfied evidence unlikely to result in conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The legal question that arises from the above is whether where an application for withdrawal under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is made on the ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence that is available, it is an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent before evidence is taken, if it was

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.494 vests broad executive discretion in Public Prosecutor subject to judicial consent to prevent abuse; no requirement for full evidentiary hearing as that would narrow section unduly; discretion based on available material aligns with magistrate's other functions.

holdings.text: s.494 CrPC applies to withdrawal applications at committal stage in sessions-triable cases.

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that in a case triable by a Court of Session, an application by the Public Prosecutor for withdrawal with the consent of the Court does not lie in the committal stage. He lays emphasis on the wording of s. 494 which says that in cases tried by jury,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section's language wide and general, applies to all non-jury cases before judgment; legislative history from 1872 Code confirms coverage of inquiry stages without exclusion; no basis for discrimination between sessions and other cases.

holdings.text: Granting consent under s.494 does not require Court to hold preliminary inquiry or record evidence as under ss.202, 209 or 253 CrPC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Would engraft unauthorized exception onto wide terms of s.494; consent checks executive discretion without turning Court into prosecutor; differs from discharge standards under other sections.

holdings.text: Court's consent under s.494 is judicial discretion exercised on available material, not limited to judicially gathered evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Bawa Faqir Singh; aligns with magistrate's investigative discretions under ss.61,167,164 etc. based on executive-provided material to prevent abuse.

holdings.text: Magistrate properly exercised discretion in granting consent to withdrawal as evidence against appellant meagre and unlikely to convict.
